Use an array to store the representative of each element, the structure will be an directed tree where each element points to a representative.
并查集实现的直观结构：一颗内向树
Therefore, the two operations will be:
find :: Eq a => DisjointSet a -> a -> a : find the representative of an element
union :: Eq a => DisjointSet a -> a -> a -> DisjointSet a : merge two sets
Trivially, find recursively finds the root of the tree, and union merges two trees by making one root the child of the other, the time complexity of both operations is \Omicron (n) since the height of the tree can be as large as n.

To optimize the trivial implementation of the union operation, we can use the merge by rank optimization.
Intuitively, we want the height of the tree to be small. Therefore, we can merge the smaller tree into the larger tree to keep the height of the tree small.

Worst Case:
仅使用按秩合并的并查集，最坏情况结构
In the worst case, a disjoint set with height h will have \sum _{k = 0}^{h} h \binom {h}{k} = h \cdot 2^{h - 1} elements, which means the depth of a tree will be logarithmic in the number of elements.
To optimize the trivial implementation of the union operation, we can use the path compression optimization.

By the definition of the equivalence relation, we know that the elements in the same equivalence class can choose the same element as the representative. Thus, we can set all the elements in the same equivalence class to point to the same, final representative when we find the representative of an element.

With the two optimizations above the time complexity of both operations can be reduced to \Omicron (\alpha (n)), where \alpha (n) is the inverse Ackermann function, which is a very slow growing function, so the time complexity of both operations is almost \Theta (1).

544concept-0001concept-0001.xmlEquivalence RelationDefinition202518
An equivalence relation（等价关系） is a binary relation \equiv on a set S, such that:
reflexive: for all x : S, x \equiv x
symmetric: for all x, y : S, if x \equiv y then y \equiv x
transitive: for all x, y, z : S, if x \equiv y and y \equiv z then x \equiv z
It's obvious that an equivalence relation can be used to partition a set into disjoint (not overlapping) subsets.
545ShanghaiTech-CS101-0002ShanghaiTech-CS101-0002.xmlDisjoint SetDefinition202518
Disjoint set（并查集） is a data structure that keeps track of equivalence classes of all elements in a set.
It supports two operations:
find(x): return the representative of the set that element x belongs to.
union(x, y): merge the sets that contain x and y.
